ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course was an in-depth and hands-on exploration into the past and present of chondrichthyan biodiversity. It was an excellent complement to the lecture course. I developed skill in the handling of specimens and knowledge of anatomy and phylogeny.
I learned practical knowledge about sharks and their relatives, learned hands-on-skills in dissection and species observations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course lie in its access to incredible specimens, both live and preserved/fossilized, and being able to connect those specimens to the information we learned in lecture.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course for anyone who is also taking the lecture; I do think that enrollment in the lecture is essential to fully appreciate the lab.

I would highly recommend this course to another student. I've never taken another lab course quite like this one, and you'll get to do so many interesting things that build on what you learn in the lecture course seamlessly. The skeletonization project brought together everything we had been learning and the skills we had been developing throughout the lab in a satisfying way, and so you feel a real sense of accomplishment at the end of this course.
